Title: Behavioral effects of triadimefon in zebrafish are associated with alterations of the dopaminergic and serotonergic pathways
Authors: Susana Paredes-Zúñiga, Nils Trost, Javiera F De La Paz, Julio Alcayaga, Miguel L Allende
Venue: Progress in Neuro-psychopharmacology and Biological Psychiatry
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "In this work we have studied, for the first time, the effects of TDF on behavior of both larval and adult zebrafish and its connection with changes in the dopaminergic and serotonergic systems."
  - "We evaluated the acute exposure of 5 dpf larvae to different concentrations of TDF, ranging from 5 mg/L to 35 mg/L."
  - "Using in vivo electrochemistry, we show that these changes could be associated with higher levels of dopamine in the brain."
  - "In this work we exploit established behavioral assays performed both in larval and adult zebrafish to assess the effects of TDF on the nervous system."
  - "To record and analyze the behavior of adult zebrafish treated with TDF 5 mg/L and 20 mg/L we followed the methods described in Cachat et al. (2011)."
  - "We took steps to ensure that we used sibling animals within experiments."
  - "All the procedures complied with the guidelines and were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of the University of Chile,"
Reasoning for "Study type":
- The study involves the evaluation of the effects of Triadimefon (TDF) on zebrafish behavior, which indicates an experimental setup where variables are manipulated (exposure to TDF) to observe outcomes.
- The use of different concentrations of TDF and the measurement of behavioral changes suggest a controlled experimental design.
- The mention of using established behavioral assays and in vivo electrochemistry further supports the experimental nature of the study.
- The study involves manipulation of conditions (exposure to TDF) and observation of effects, which is characteristic of an experimental study.

Title: Carbofuran induces increased anxiety-like behaviors in female zebrafish (Danio rerio) through disturbing dopaminergic/ norepinephrinergic system
Authors: Shuang Liu, Miao Yu, Xincen Xie, Yiran Ru, Shaoguo Ru, David Volz
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "In this study, female zebrafish were used as test organisms to evaluate the effects of carbofuran exposure for 48 h on anxiety-like behaviors using a novel tank diving test."
  - "The exposure experiments were conducted in 5-L glass tanks filled with 4 L of carbofuran exposure or solvent control medium, each tank contained 6 female zebrafish."
  - "Fish were exposed to various concentrations of carbofuran or 0.005% (v/v) DMSO for 48 h, and the exposure solutions were totally replaced every 24 h."
  - "All experiments were repeated twice."
  - "Zebrafish used for neurotransmitter-targeted metabolic testing were exposed to 20 L treatment solution in 30-L glass aquarium, with 30 fish per aquarium and 4 aquariums per treatment group (50 mg/L carbofuran and solvent control, respectively)."
  - "Inhibitor of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), a-Methyltyrosine (AMPT, Aladdin, Shanghai, China), was used to confirm the role of TH in carbofuran-induced anxiety-like behaviors, through intraperitoneal injection method described by Kinkel et al. (2010)."
  - "The novel tank diving test showed that the combined exposure to 50 mg/L of carbofuran and AMPT reduced the latency to the upper half (Fig. 6A ), zebrafish had an increased trend in upper movement, and erratic movements were also significantly decreased compared with those in carbofuran-alone treatment (Fig. 6B, C, D"
Reasoning for "Study type":
- The study involves controlled exposure of zebrafish to different concentrations of carbofuran and a solvent control, which is characteristic of an experimental study.
- The use of a novel tank diving test to evaluate anxiety-like behaviors and the manipulation of neurotransmitter systems through the use of an inhibitor (AMPT) further supports the experimental nature of the study.
- The repetition of experiments and the use of control groups are typical of experimental design.
- The study involves direct manipulation of variables (carbofuran exposure and AMPT treatment) to observe effects on anxiety-like behaviors, which is a hallmark of experimental research.

Title: Embryonic atrazine exposure and later in life behavioral and brain transcriptomic, epigenetic, and pathological alterations in adult male zebrafish
Authors: Katharine A Horzmann, Li F Lin, Boghos Taslakjian, Chongli Yuan, Jennifer L Freeman
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "we evaluated male zebrafish brain sections for histopathological changes and performed morphometric analysis of cellular density in three regions of the zebrafish brain that have been associated with neurological conditions"
  - "We also performed transcriptomic analysis of male zebrafish brain at 9 mpf to evaluate the persistence of gene expression changes through the zebrafish life course and to provide a transcriptomic basis of any behavioral phenotype observed."
  - "We evaluated the performance of 9 mpf male zebrafish in a battery of three neurobehavioral tests of anxiety, the novel tank test (NTT), the light dark box (LDB), and an open field test (OFT) to determine if embryonic ATZ exposure causes functional changes in neurobehavior."
  - "Zebrafish (Danio rerio) embryos were exposed to 0, 0.3, 3, or 30 ppb ATZ during embryogenesis (1-72 hours post fertilization (hpf)), then rinsed, and raised to maturity."
Reasoning for "Study type":
- The study involves exposing zebrafish embryos to different concentrations of atrazine (ATZ) and then observing the effects on their behavior, brain transcriptome, and histopathology at a later stage. This indicates a controlled manipulation of an independent variable (ATZ exposure) to observe its effects on dependent variables (behavior, gene expression, histopathology), which is characteristic of an experimental study.
- The use of specific concentrations of ATZ and the control group (0 ppb ATZ) further supports the experimental nature of the study, as it allows for the comparison of outcomes between treated and untreated groups.
- The study involves multiple tests and analyses (behavioral tests, transcriptomic analysis, histopathology, and methylation status evaluation), which are typical components of an experimental study design.

Title: Neurobehavioral Impairments Caused by Developmental Imidacloprid Exposure in Zebrafish
Authors: Emily B Crosby, Jordan M Bailey, Anthony N Oliveri, Edward D Levin
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "Animals destined for larval, adolescent or adult testing were dosed separately but identically: approximately 2 h post fertilization (hpf), eggs were inspected under a microscope, and placed in glass Petri dishes at a density of 35-eggs/50 mL aqueous solution and maintained in an incubator (28°C, 14 h light/10 h dark cycle) for 5 d."
  - "All subjects used in the study were bred in the lab from AB* and 5D progenitors."
  - "The functional effects of developmental exposure to both imidacloprid and nicotine were assessed in larvae using an activity assay and during adolescence and adulthood using a battery of neurobehavioral assays,"
  - "Zebrafish were exposed via immersion in aqueous solutions containing 45 μM or 60 μM of imidacloprid or nicotine (or vehicle control) from 4 h to 5 d post fertilization."
  - "Using zebrafish, we investigated the neurobehavioral effects of developmental exposure to imidacloprid, a prototypic neonicotinoid pesticide."
Reasoning for "Study type":
- The study involves the intentional exposure of zebrafish to imidacloprid and nicotine to observe their effects on neurobehavioral development. This indicates a controlled manipulation of variables, which is characteristic of an experimental study.
- The use of a control group and the administration of different doses of imidacloprid and nicotine further support the experimental nature of the study.
- The study is conducted in a controlled laboratory setting, where zebrafish are bred and exposed to specific conditions, which is typical of experimental research.
- The study aims to assess the effects of developmental exposure to imidacloprid and nicotine, which involves manipulating the exposure variable to observe its impact on neurobehavioral outcomes.

Title: Quantitative assessment of cypermethrin induced behavioural and biochemical anomalies in adult zebrafish
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "We observed that cypermethrin exposure at 25 μg/L concentration showed significant reduction in total distance travelled in the open-field tank (OFT) behavioural test (Fig. 1 ), so further experiments were done using this concentration."
  - "For the investigation of cypermethrin potential to induce behavioural abnormalities, five adult zebrafish per treatment group (control and 25 μg/L cypermethrin) were used per trial."
  - "For the screening of effective dose of cypermethrin which can be used for the induction of behavioural abnormalities upon short exposure, adult zebrafish in a group of five fishes per treatment were exposed for 30 min to different test concentrations of cypermethrin viz. 0 μg/L (0 ppb) (used as control), or 0.25 μg/L (0.25 ppb), 2.5 μg/L (2.5 ppb) and 25 μg/L (25 ppb) concentration of cypermethrin."
  - "Here we used videogram and automated tracking approach to quantitatively assess behavioural toxicity induced by the short exposure of cypermethrin to adult zebrafish."
Reasoning for "Study type":
- The study involves exposing adult zebrafish to different concentrations of cypermethrin and observing the effects on their behavior. This indicates an experimental setup where variables are controlled and manipulated to observe outcomes.
- The use of a control group and treatment groups with different concentrations of cypermethrin suggests an experimental design where the effect of the treatment (cypermethrin exposure) is being tested.
- The study involves quantitative assessment and measurement of behavioral changes, which is typical of experimental research where specific outcomes are measured in response to controlled conditions.

Title: The organophosphate insecticide diazinon and aging: Neurobehavioral and mitochondrial effects in zebrafish exposed as embryos or during aging
Authors: Jonna Boyda, Andrew B Hawkey, Zade R Holloway, Rafael Trevisan, Richard T Di Giulio, Edward D Levin, G A Richardson
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "The zebrafish was the model organism in this research project because of several notable advantages. Zebrafish are an established model for early developmental and are increasingly being adapted for use in aging research, based on a strong degree of sequence and functional homology with humans"
  - "In the first study (referred to as study 1), a group of larval zebrafish were embryonically exposed to DZN (e.g. a critical developmental period). In the second study (referred to as study 2), an adult group of zebrafish was acutely exposed (14 months, pre-scenescent/ prior to age-related increases in spontaneous death and behavioral dysfunction)."
  - "The goal of this experiment was to determine the interactions of maturation, aging and neurotoxicant effects through two studies, with one study examining early developmental toxicant exposure, and a second study examining later toxicant exposure effects on neurobehavioral and mitochondrial function in the zebrafish (Danio rerio) model."
  - "The present study examined diazinon (DZN), an OP, to determine the neurobehavioral consequences, in addition to mitochondrial dysfunction on a macroscale (whole organism basal respiration) and on a microscale (whole organ mitochondrial respiration), using zebrafish (ZF) as a model."
Reasoning for "Study type":
- The study involves controlled exposure of zebrafish to diazinon at different developmental stages, which is characteristic of an experimental study.
- The use of a model organism (zebrafish) and controlled exposure conditions further supports the classification as an experimental study.
- The study design includes two distinct experiments: one examining early developmental exposure and another examining exposure in adulthood, both of which are typical of experimental research.
- The study aims to determine the effects of diazinon on neurobehavioral and mitochondrial functions, which is achieved through experimental manipulation and observation.

Title: Tributyltin enhanced anxiety of adult male zebrafish through elevating cortisol level and disruption in serotonin, dopamine and gamma-aminobutyric acid neurotransmitter pathways

- "The fish were then exposed to corresponding concentrations of TBT for 28 days with a 14 h/10 h light/ darkness photoperiod and fed with Artemia nauplii (Artemia International LCC, USA) and flake food daily (1.5% body weight per day) during exposure."
  - "After exposure, anxiety responses, reflected by 1) the total time spent in the lower half of the tank, 2) the onset time to the higher half, 3) frequency of turning and 4) the total duration of freezing, were investigated."
  - "To confirm our hypothesis, a 28-day exposure of TBT (100 and 500 ng/L) was performed on adult male zebrafish."

Title: Zebrafish provide a sensitive model of persisting neurobehavioral effects of developmental chlorpyrifos exposure: Comparison with nicotine and pilocarpine effects and relationship to dopamine deficits

- "The experimental protocol was approved by the Duke University Institutional Committee for the use of animal subjects."

  - "Selected embryos were separated into five treatment groups: 0. From our experience with pilot experiments we chose concentrations that did not increase embryonic fatalities or malformations above control rates."
